channel.title: Wired News: Top Stories
channel.description: Get the latest headlines from Wired News, the net's leading chronicle of how technology affects our lives, culture and work.
channel.copyright: © Copyright 2006, Lycos, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

item.title: The 2006 Rave Awards
item.description:
Wired magazine's annual salute to the rebels and revolutionaries shaping the wired world.
Music: Clap Your Hands Say Yeah
Architecture: Cameron Sinclair and Kate Stohr
Podcasting: The Ricky Gervais Show
Policy: The intelligent design judge
TV: The Lazy Sunday guys
Renegades: George Clooney, Mark Cuban, Jeff Skoll and Steven Soderbergh
Plus: The First-Ever Steve Jobs Award

item.title: Security vs. Privacy: The Rematch
item.description: Let's put an end to this false debate. Privacy and security aren't mutually exclusive -- in a free society, we can have both. Commentary by Jennifer Granick.

item.title: In Praise of Car Rentals
item.description: It's easy to pretend you're Speed Racer while driving an auto tricked out with steering-wheel buttons galore. Commentary by Lore Sjöberg.

item.title: Rumors Rife of Internet Mergers
item.description: With internet growth tapering off, the industry may be looking at a period of consolidation that could involve some of the biggest players. An eBay-Yahoo merger is the one that intrigues analysts the most.

item.title: Introducing … the 2006 Pixar!
item.description: The animation giant's new CG adventure Cars is born from its creators' zeal for the wheel. By Paul Davidson from Wired magazine.

item.title: Going Gaga Over Gas Guzzlers
item.description: Although incredibly easy on the eyes, these luxury cars will cause a severe pain in the wallet when you pull up to the pump. From Forbes.com.

item.title: Microsoft Tempts Consumers
item.description: Vista is on display but its actual date to market remains sketchy. Plus: Morpheus maker StreamCast strives to put competitors to sleep.... Salesforce.com pushes web-delivered software.... and more.

item.title: Are Cloned Animals Cuter?
item.description: Pink piglets, fluffy kittens -- it's a subjective matter, so you decide. Plus: Cloned mules get ready to race.... Bird flu spreads from human to human but luckily doesn't mutate. In Bodyhack.

item.title: Cell Phone Sends Music to Radios
item.description: Sprint's new Fusic comes with a built-in FM transmitter. Plus: Is Google launching a music service? In Listening Post.

item.title: Click, Drag, Type and Swear
item.description: ClickDragType is a game with simple instructions and brain-boggling challenges. Plus: Gorgeous silhouette animation is about war or something. In Table of Malcontents.

item.title: Hillary Is Hot for Hybrids
item.description: Candidates put alternative fuels at the center of the political debate. Plus: A Bluetooth security system requires the owner's mobile phone for the car to start. In Autopia.

item.title: Rants 'n' Raves: Views on Freedom
item.description: Readers debate Wired News' publishing of the AT&T documents.

item.title: WHO Probes Bird Flu Spread
item.description: The World Health Organization warns that human-to-human transmission of the disease could be to blame for the deaths of six Indonesians.

item.title: Bryan Singer & the Man of Steel
item.description: The mild-mannered director who brought us X-Men and The Usual Suspects is on a mission to save Superman from the Hollywood hacks. By Thomas Goetz from Wired magazine.Plus: The Myth of Superman by Neil Gaiman and Adam Rogers.

item.title: The Dead Formats Society
item.description: The flux of digital formats is not always fodder for lamentation. Sometimes we must destroy in order to preserve. Commentary by Momus.

item.title: Doom 3 Like You've Never Seen
item.description: If you think dual-card graphics systems are too complex and expensive, guess again. By Bruce Gain.

item.title: Gadget Lab: Mini Means Business
item.description: The Mac mini comes through in a pinch, an Elvis cam gets no love and a laser pointer shows the way to jail. In Gadget Lab.

item.title: Whistle-Blower's Evidence, Uncut
item.description: Former AT&T technician Mark Klein's firsthand account tells how he discovered a secret room routing American internet traffic straight to the NSA -- along with all the documents he says prove his case.

item.title: Why We Published the AT&T Docs
item.description: The public's right to see the documents provided by whistle-blower Mark Klein trumps the telecommunications giant's secrecy claims. By Evan Hansen, Wired News' editor in chief.

item.title: Tales From Packaging Hell
item.description: Anecdotes abound of gadget-wrap injuries. Is it time the industry reviewed its Fort Knox packaging policies? By Steve Friess.

item.title: The Game Within the Game
item.description: Meet Tringo, a video game created inside a video game that has taken on a life all its own. Simply conceived -- it plays as if Tetris mated with bingo -- it is nevertheless changing the way people look at their virtual world. Commentary by Clive Thompson.

item.title: New Mario Is Best DS Game Ever
item.description: When it comes to the Nintendo DS, does it get any better than nostalgic charm and tight, challenging, old-school gameplay? By Chris Kohler.

item.title: DIY Phone Club Channels PC Past
item.description: The Homebrew Mobile Phone Club wants to bring fresh ideas and the open-source philosophy to the largely closed world of mobile phone development. By Elizabeth Biddlecombe.

item.title: Happy Sex Is Healthy Sex
item.description: An educator taps the internet to promote sexual health and sex education. It seems to be working. Commentary by Regina Lynn.

item.title: The Da Vinci Code's Plot Thickens
item.description: Sure, it's slick and based on a controversial best seller. But is the movie version of Dan Brown's abominably written potboiler any good? By Jason Silverman.

item.title: The Eternal Value of Privacy
item.description: Supporters of wholesale government surveillance are fond of saying that only the guilty should be worried about spying. Let's put that spurious argument out to pasture once and for all. Commentary by Bruce Schneier.
